title: Swimming with sharks off Ningaloo Reef
text:
Turning into his wake, I find his tail fin inches from my mask; it flicks gracefully from side to side, sending reverberations through this underwater universe like some prehistoric communique.

Back on dry land – in fact it is parched, this brush-speckled limestone coastline – I sink into my own luxury digs, Sal Salis Ningaloo Reef. This discrete safari camp would be a veritable oasis if not for the fact that there are no trees hereabouts and the tents appear to have evolved from the dunes. It is the only privately operated camp in the Cape Range National Park, which has itself been sequestrated from surrounding pastoral stations.

The sublime location of Sal Salis Ningaloo Reef resort.

To get here, I have travelled from Exmouth to the north via a road that sweeps past a caravan park owned by mining magnate Andrew “Twiggy” Forrest (primed for resort-style development) and along an empty stretch of orange dirt rimmed by a ribbon of blue sea.

The ocean is an extension of the dunes, the dunes’ earthly ripples sent from the ocean. All of it is encompassed in the UNESCO heritage listing, and so this human settlement must operate according to regulations as strict as those pertaining to the marine park.

Every 'room' has a view and is within easy reach of the beach.

My tent is tucked behind the dunes, a capsule of understated luxury that gives concession to its fragile environment – long-drop toilets, a limited allocation of water, power that is mostly solar-generated. When the camp is dismantled at the end of the dry season in November, little evidence of its existence will be left behind.

Yardie Creek Gorge in Cape Range National Park, north of Ningaloo Reef. Catherine Marshall

Beyond the coastal plain lie jagged gullies and ridges, a landscape enlivened by the fluorescent new leaves of kurrajong trees. At Yardie Creek – as far south as the road will take us – Sal Salis guide Cheyenne Riddle points out warty apple bushes protruding from cracks in the rock and bush figs ripening on the tree.

“The fruit goes from green to yellow to purple,” she says. “They’re a really good source of food for the rock wallabies that live here.”

Advertisement

Appearing on cue, the wallabies leap around the rock face, textured feet and long tails improving their dexterity. Undercut by waterways and sink holes and caves, this immense karst was once an ocean floor; fossils are embedded in it, brain-shaped imprints marooned from the ocean nearby.

That night, I leave the tent flaps open and am cooled by a southerly washing off the sea. In the morning, it’s just a few steps from breakfast to the beach, and a handful of strokes from the shore to the reef.

Back at camp after a hard day's swimming and exploring.

My mask is a portal to the past, for beneath the water’s surface is a vision of what that limestone slab might have looked like at the beginning of time: an endless forest of sculpted corals shot through with glittering sunrays and bright, darting fish. It’s the Garden of Eden, submerged beneath the limpid waters of a remote West Australian seashore.

The Milky Way tends to steal the show at night.

NEED TO KNOW



Getting there Qantas operates daily flights from Perth to Exmouth. The airline is considering extending its special weekend fares trial – undertaken in conjunction with the WA government this year – to 2020’s peak season. Avis Australia is offering reduced drop-off fees on one-way rentals between Perth and Exmouth in an effort to make the region more accessible and affordable. The promotion is effective for bookings between April and October 2019 and 2020. See avis.com.au and australiascoralcoast.com.

Staying there Sal Salis Ningaloo Reef is open from mid March to the end of October; rates start at $900 a person per night, based on a two-night minimum stay and include accommodation with eco-ensuite bathroom, chef-prepared meals and snacks as well as drinks from a select open bar, national park entrance fees and guided activities. Whale Shark excursions can be organised through the camp. See salsalis.com.au

Excursions Live Ningaloo offers small-group, full-day whale shark swimming tours (maximum of 10 guests) for confident swimmers aged 10 and older. Tours run between March and August, cost $550 a person and include spotter plane guidance, coral reef and ocean swims, wetsuits and snorkelling equipment, and lunch. See liveningaloo.com.au.

INSIDER TIP

The COMO The Treasury in Perth recently launched an Escape to Ningaloo package comprising two nights in a heritage room at the hotel, and three nights in a Wilderness Tent at Sal Salis. Prices from $4187 a person, based on twin share; return flights from Perth to Exmouth from $400 a person. See comohotels.com/en/thetreasury/offers

The writer was a guest of Tourism Western Australia.
description: A stay at the pitch and pack-up eco camp of Sal Salis on Western Australia's pristine north coast is memorable for so many reasons.
